natural problem: How many triangles can be formed using the vertices of a regular dodecagon (a 12-sided polygon)?
natural solution: No three vertices are collinear, so any combination of 3 vertices will make a triangle. Choosing 3 out of 12 is $\binom{12}{3}=\boxed{220}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n triangles :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "triangles = binomial n 3"
shows  "triangles = 220"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many triangles can be formed using the vertices of a regular dodecagon (a 12-sided polygon)? The final Answer is 220
 ### Proof
 No three vertices are collinear, so any combination of 3 vertices will make a triangle. Choosing 3 out of 12 is $\binom{12}{3}=\boxed{220}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n triangles :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
and h1 : "triangles = binomial n 3"
shows  "triangles = 220"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many triangles can be formed by connecting any three vertices of a regular 12-sided polygon? The final answer is 220.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes dodecagon_vertices :: nat
assumes h0 : "dodecagon_vertices = 12"
shows  "binomial dodecagon_vertices 3 = 220"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many triangles can be formed using the vertices of a regular dodecagon (a 12-sided polygon)? The final Answer is 220
 ### Proof
 No three vertices are collinear, so any combination of 3 vertices will make a triangle. Choosing 3 out of 12 is $\binom{12}{3}=\boxed{220}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes dodecagon_vertices :: nat
assumes h0 : "dodecagon_vertices = 12"
shows  "binomial dodecagon_vertices 3 = 220"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many ways can 3 vertices be chosen from a regular dodecagon (a 12-sided polygon)? The final answer is 220.

shows  "binomial n 3 = 220"
a_2.formal solution:

 ### Proof
 No three vertices are collinear, so any combination of 3 vertices will make a triangle. Choosing 3 out of 12 is $\binom{12}{3}=\boxed{220}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
shows  "binomial n 3 = 220"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Calculate the binomial coefficient for n = 12 and k = 3. The final answer is 220.

fixes n triangles :: nat

 proof-

a_3.informal problem: How many triangles can be formed by choosing 3 vertices from a set of 12 points? The final answer is 220.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
shows  "220 = (n choose 3)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many triangles can be formed using the vertices of a regular dodecagon (a 12-sided polygon)? The final Answer is 220
 ### Proof
 No three vertices are collinear, so any combination of 3 vertices will make a triangle. Choosing 3 out of 12 is $\binom{12}{3}=\boxed{220}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 12"
shows  "220 = (n choose 3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the number of combinations when choosing 3 items from a set of 12 items. The final answer is 220.
